articles.headline: U.S. to Require Negative Covid Tests for Travelers Coming From China
articles.snippet: Amid concerns about a coronavirus surge in Beijing, the Biden administration announced the change in policy for those entering the United States from China, including Hong Kong and Macau.
articles.abstract: Amid concerns about a coronavirus surge in Beijing, the Biden administration announced the change in policy for those entering the United States from China, including Hong Kong and Macau.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration, fearful that a surge of coronavirus infections in Beijing could spawn a new and more dangerous variant, announced on Wednesday that it will require travelers from China, including Hong Kong and Macau, to present negative Covid-19 tests before entering the United States.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: Hard-Line Positions by Russia and Ukraine Dim Hope for Peace Talks
articles.snippet: Both Moscow and Kyiv say they are ready to talk, but their terms for sitting down at a negotiating table suggest otherwise.
articles.abstract: Both Moscow and Kyiv say they are ready to talk, but their terms for sitting down at a negotiating table suggest otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the battle for Ukraine turns into a bloody, mile-by-mile fight in numbing cold, Ukrainian and Russian officials have insisted that they are willing to discuss making peace.

articles.headline: 10 Months Into Job, Southwest’s C.E.O. Faces a Giant Crisis
articles.snippet: Bob Jordan, the airline’s top executive, heralded the company’s performance just weeks before the storm highlighted gaping weaknesses in its operations.
articles.abstract: Bob Jordan, the airline’s top executive, heralded the company’s performance just weeks before the storm highlighted gaping weaknesses in its operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Southwest Airlines made it through Thanksgiving with few flight cancellations, Bob Jordan, the company’s chief executive, was in a celebratory mood. At a meeting with Wall Street analysts and investors this month at the New York Stock Exchange, he said the company’s performance had been “just incredible.”
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Isabella Simonetti

articles.headline: The Tech That Will Invade Our Lives in 2023
articles.snippet: Say hello to new-and-improved A.I. assistants, and move over to brands like Twitter and Tesla.
articles.abstract: Say hello to new-and-improved A.I. assistants, and move over to brands like Twitter and Tesla.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each year, I look ahead at what’s new in technology to predict the tech that may affect your life in a big way — and the tech that will most likely be a fad.

articles.headline: The 2022 Good Tech Awards
articles.snippet: Nuclear fusion, generative A.I., bee tracking and more. There’s a lot to like.
articles.abstract: Nuclear fusion, generative A.I., bee tracking and more. There’s a lot to like.
articles.lead_paragraph: The year 2022, in the tech world, was one of big leaps and even bigger pratfalls.

articles.headline: Its Reputation in Tatters, Southwest Aims to Resume Normal Schedule on Friday
articles.snippet: Nearly a week after a winter storm upended holiday travel across the U.S., the airline says it is close to resuming service “with minimal disruptions.”
articles.abstract: Nearly a week after a winter storm upended holiday travel across the U.S., the airline says it is close to resuming service “with minimal disruptions.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines, caught in a vexing tangle of misplaced staff and technical problems since last week’s winter storm, said Thursday that it planned to return to normal operations on Friday “with minimal disruptions.”
articles.byline: By Isabella Simonetti, Peter Eavis and Soumya Karlamangla
